details.description: The most sampled drum break in history, from the B-side of a soul record.
details.cultural_significance: Cornerstone of jungle music, used in thousands of tracks.
details.historical_note: Originally performed by Gregory C. Coleman, who died homeless without royalties.

details.description: Deep, rumbling bass designed to be felt in car audio systems.
details.cultural_significance: Emerged in modern DNB around 2010, defining the 'foghorn' sound.
details.production_technique: Created using layered sine waves with distortion and pitch modulation.

details.description: Fast breakbeat patterns typical of modern drum and bass.
details.cultural_significance: Defines the modern DNB tempo, faster than original jungle.
details.typical_usage: Main rhythm element in DNB tracks
details.historical_note: DNB evolved from jungle in the mid-1990s with faster tempos and cleaner production.

details.description: A growling, distorted bass sound with rich harmonics.
details.cultural_significance: Named after Kevin Saunderson's 'Just Want Another Chance' (1988).
details.typical_usage: Mid-range bass element, often paired with sub bass
details.production_technique: Multiple detuned sawtooth waves with filter modulation.

details.description: Atmospheric elements that provide texture and context.
details.cultural_significance: Creates the 'vibe' of jungle/DNB, often sampling Jamaican dub or film dialogue.
details.historical_note: Sampling culture is central to jungle's development, drawing from reggae soundsystem culture.

details.description: Funky drum break produced by James Brown.
details.cultural_significance: Second most sampled break after the Amen Break.
details.typical_usage: Often used for variation in jungle tracks
details.historical_note: Popularized in hip-hop by Rob Base & DJ E-Z Rock's 'It Takes Two'.

details.description: Deep, rhythmic bassline inspired by reggae and dub music.
details.cultural_significance: Links jungle directly to its Jamaican soundsystem roots.
details.typical_usage: Often slowed down or time-stretched to fit jungle's tempo
details.production_technique: Often sampled from reggae records or recreated with round sub bass.
